fact_list.fact_text: Exceeding the speed limit of a vehicle by 1 to 20 kilometres per hour is an offense.
Exceeding the speed limit of a road by 1 to 20 kilometres per hour is an offense.
Failing to give way to oncoming traffic at a controlled junction is an offense.
Failing to give way at an uncontrolled junction is an offense.
Failing to give way at a junction is an offense.
Failing to give way at a roundabout is an offense.
Crossing double white lines is an offense.
Crossing a road divider is an offense.
Obstructing the flow of traffic is an offense.
Forming up incorrectly when turning left or right is an offense.
Failing to give way to an ambulance, fire brigade or police vehicle is an offense.
Driving while carrying a load on a motor vehicle in a dangerous manner is an offense.
Stopping on the shoulder or verge of an expressway is an offense.
Stopping or remaining at rest on the carriageway of an expressway is an offense.
Exceeding the speed limit of a vehicle by 21 to 30 kilometres per hour is an offense.
Exceeding the speed limit of a road by 21 to 30 kilometres per hour is an offense.
Driving on the shoulder of an expressway is an offense.
Failing to securely tie or attach goods to a goods vehicle to prevent them from falling off the vehicle is an offense.
Offenses committed by motorists at a pedestrian crossing is an offense.
Driving or riding against the flow of traffic as indicated by traffic signs is an offense.
Careless driving is an offense.
Carrying passengers on a motor vehicle or trailer in a dangerous manner is an offense.
Reversing unnecessarily along an expressway is an offense.
Failing to obey the 1.1 metre height restriction for persons carried on an open deck goods vehicle is an offense.
Carrying passengers when the clear floor space of the open deck of a goods vehicle available for each passenger is insufficient is an offense.
Exceeding the speed limit of a vehicle by 31 to 40 kilometres per hour is an offense.
Exceeding the speed limit of a road by 31 to 40 kilometres per hour is an offense.
Driving without due care or reasonable consideration for other road users is an offense.
Carrying passengers on a goods vehicle in a dangerous manner is an offense.
Exceeding the speed limit of a vehicle by 41 to 50 kilometres per hour is an offense.
Exceeding the speed limit of a road by 41 to 50 kilometres per hour is an offense.
Failing to conform to traffic light signals is an offense.
Use of mobile telephone while driving for the 1st offense carries a fine not exceeding $1000 or jail up to 6 months or both.
Use of mobile telephone while driving for the 2nd and subsequent offense carries a fine not exceeding $2000 or jail up to 12 months or both.
Exceeding the speed limit of a vehicle by 51 to 60 kilometres per hour is an offense.
Exceeding the speed limit of a road by 51 to 60 kilometres per hour is an offense.
Exceeding the speed limit of a vehicle by more than 60 kilometres per hour is an offense.
Exceeding the speed limit of a road by more than 60 kilometres per hour is an offense.
Reckless or dangerous driving is an offense.
Upon reaching the stipulated age limits, all license holders are required by law to undergo a medical examination to certify their fitness to drive in order to validate their driving license.

A Class 2B, 2A, 2, 3, 3A, 3C and 3CA driving license shall cease to be valid upon the holder reaching the age of 65 years, unless the holder is certified physically and mentally fit to drive by a Singapore registered medical practitioner every 3 years from the age of 65.

A Class 4A, 4 and 5 driving license shall cease to be valid upon the holder reaching the age of 65 years, unless the holder is certified physically and mentally fit to drive by a Singapore registered medical practitioner every year from age of 65 till age of 74 and has passed a Proficiency Driving Test at the driving test center.
